question: What are the key results?
actual_generation:
The key results from the context are:

- The Transformer model achieves better BLEU scores than previous state-of-the-art models on English-to-German (EN-DE) and English-to-French (EN-FR) translation tasks at a fraction of the training cost.
- On the WMT 2014 English-to-French translation task, the Transformer (big) model achieves a BLEU score of 41.8, outperforming all previously published single models, while using less than one-quarter of the training cost of the previous state-of-the-art model.
- For English-to-German, the Transformer (big) model achieves a BLEU score of 28.4, which is higher than other models listed.
- The Transformer (base) model achieves BLEU scores of 27.3 (EN-DE) and 38.1 (EN-FR) with significantly lower training costs (3.3·10^18 FLOPs) compared to other models.
- The Transformer (big) model requires 2.3·10^19 FLOPs for training, which is much less than other competitive models that require on the order of 10^20 FLOPs or more.
- The model variations experiments show that multiple attention heads improve performance, bigger models perform better, and dropout is important to avoid overfitting.
- The Transformer also generalizes well to English constituency parsing, achieving competitive F1 scores (up to 92.7 in semi-supervised settings) without task-specific tuning.

Overall, the Transformer architecture provides state-of-the-art translation quality with significantly reduced training costs and demonstrates strong generalization to other NLP tasks.
